unit_learning_outcomes.description: Apply skills in the use of standard tools and techniques for editing, both in print and in electronic media.
Analyse standard guidelines set out for editorial work, and identify scope for individual decision making.
Appraise the effectiveness of different font and layout choices, and assess their impact on legibility.
Examine texts for variable language use, and justify their suitability for different audiences.

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Reading of online notes and additional readings related to weekly lectures.
Engagement in online discussion board based around weekly topic
Investigation into changes in current current editorial practices, to be brought to particular relevant weekly discussions (e.g. web-editing, inclusive language)

enrolment_rules.description: Admission to GradCertEditElecPub or MCrWrit or GradDipCrWrit or MAccComm

assessments.description: 1.	Analysis of strengths and weaknesses of editing standards in an online forum. Each student has to present 2 aspects of editorial roles that could be better covered by the official standards, defend their position, and critique the positions of other students on at least 2 other aspects of editorial work.  (1500 words over multiple statements/responses)
Identify and solve legibility issues in a text that students choose themselves (1000 words plus design mockup)
Identification of different regional features that require editing in texts. (500 words plus practical editing task)

Identification and discussion of common usage issues in an online forum. Each student has to present 2 language usage issues and argue for or against their validity based on authoritative references. They also have to critique the position of other students on at least 2 other usage issues. (1500 words over multiple statements/responses)

school.value: Faculty of Medicine, Health and Human Sciences

data.description: This unit lays the groundwork for professional editing, focusing first on the roles and skills of the editor, as defined by the editorial standards set in Australia (the Australian Standards for Editorial Practice (ASEP 2012) and the Institute of Professional Editors' Accreditation Board exam); and those set overseas by professional organisations in Canada, the US and the UK. It examines the different requirements for copyediting on hardcopy and on screen, and the 'tools' and resources editors can draw on. Reference guides in style, usage and grammar are reviewed, as well as regional (British v. American) preferences, and issues of editorial policy in relation to inclusive language. Selections in typography and layout for optimal legibility are also discussed.
data.title: Tools for Editing
